Crisis.Name: Human Trafficking
Crisis.EconomicImpact: 2005 ILO estimate of a gloval annual profit of $31.6 billion

Crisis.Name: Holocaust
Crisis.EconomicImpact: Average GDP of regions in Russia with a notable diminishment of Jewish citizens was 23% lower than the Russian average

Crisis.Name: 2010 eruptions of Eyjafjallajokull
Crisis.EconomicImpact: The eruption caused large scale disruption to air travel, and had some effects on the farming industry in Iceland.

Crisis.Name: 2011 Egyptian Revolution
Crisis.EconomicImpact: The protests paralyzed the country's economy, shutting down offices, shops, and banks throughout Egypt's major cities. There has also been a negative effect on Egypt's tourist industry, which makes up 5 to 6 percent of its GDP.

Crisis.Name: Chernobyl Disaster
Crisis.WaysToHelp: Providing room and board for refugees

Crisis.Name: Weapons of mass destruction in North Korea
U2 Incident
Crisis.ResourceNeeded: Foreign relations capital and a new U-2 spy plane.
Crisis.WaysToHelp: Keep a cool head and dont let it end in a nuclear holocaust.

ExternalResources.Citation: Powers, Francis Gary (1970). Operation Overflight (Hodder and Stoughton Ltd, 1971 (hard cover) ISBN 978-0-340-14823-5 ed.)

Crisis.Name: Enron Collapse
Crisis.EconomicImpact: Greatest stock value loss in peaceful times and the largest bankruptcy in American history.

Crisis.Name: Great Depression
Crisis.EconomicImpact: US economy declined after the crash, and many other countries began to follow suit.

Crisis.Name: 2008 Financial Crisis
Crisis.EconomicImpact: Declines in consumption and investment. Housing prices fell 20%.

Crisis.Name: 1973 Oil Crisis

HumanImpact.Type: Financial loss as well as panic over the possibility of war.

Crisis.EconomicImpact: The price of oil increased 400% leading to economic leverage and wealth for oil-producing countries in the middle east.

Crisis.Name: United States Corn Epidemic of 1970
Crisis.EconomicImpact: Spikes in corn and livestock trading overnight, leading to some farmers becoming extremely wealthy overnight.

Crisis.Name: World War Two
Crisis.EconomicImpact: US emerged much more wealthy than any other nation despite the global economy's heavy suffering.

Crisis.Name: Greek Economic Collapse

HumanImpact.Type: Right-wing party linked to anti-immigrant violence.

Crisis.EconomicImpact: Nearly brought down the entire country and removal from the European Union.

Crisis.Name: Russian Financial Crisis

HumanImpact.Type: Huge wave of unemployment and social unrest.

Crisis.EconomicImpact: Inevitable recession, consumer price inflation, unemployment at a 7 year high.

Crisis.Name: Yellowstone Forest Fires of 1988
Crisis.EconomicImpact: Structural Damage: $3 million; Money Spent Fighting Fires: $120 million
Crisis.ResourceNeeded: 120 helicopters and planes with over 18000 hours of flight time; Over 100 fire engines; 1.4 million gallons of fire retardant; 10 million gallons of water; 9000 firefighters; 4000 US military personell

Crisis.Name: Great Flood of 1993

Location.Region: Mississippi, Louisiana, Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska

Crisis.ResourceNeeded: Sandbags; Army Corps of Engineers; Army National Guard; American Red Cross

Organization.Name: Doctors Without Borders
Organization.History: Doctors without Borders was created in 1971, in the aftermath of the Biafra secession, by a small group of French doctors and journalist

Organization.Name: World Bank Group
Organization.History: The World Bank activities are focused on developing countries, in fields such as human development, environmental protection infrasctructure, large industrial construction projects, and governance.

PostalAddress.StreetAddress: The World Bank 1818 H Street, N.W.

Organization.Name: Africare
Organization.History: Founded September 20, 1970 in Washington D.C. by William O. Kirker, Barbara Kirker, and C. Payne Lucas

Organization.Name: Human Trafficking Awareness Partnership
Organization.History: Founded by Ms. Nola Theiss in Sanibel, Florida in 2006

Organization.Name: NATO
Organization.History: For its first few years, NATO was not much more than a political association. However, the Korean War galvanized the member states, and an integrated military structure was built up under the direction of two US supreme commanders. The course of the Cold War led to a rivalry with nations of the Warsaw Pact, which formed in 1955. The first NATO Secretary General, Lord Ismay, stated in 1949 that the organization's goal was to keep the Russians out, the Americans in, and the Germans down. Doubts over the strength of the relationship between the European states and the United States ebbed and flowed, along with doubts over the credibility of the NATO defence against a prospective Soviet invasion doubts that led to the development of the independent French nuclear deterrent and the withdrawal of the French from NATO's military structure in 1966.

Organization.Name: World Health Organization
Organization.History: The WHO is one of the first things that the founders of the UN discussed: setting up a global health organization. WHO.s Constitution came into force on 7 April 1948 . a date we now celebrate every year as World Health Day.

Organization.Name: Amnesty International
Organization.History: Amnesty International was founded in London in July 1961 by English labour lawyer Peter Benenson. By the mid-1960s Amnesty International's global presence was growing and an International Secretariat and International Executive Committee were established to manage Amnesty International's national organisations, called 'Sections', which had appeared in several countries.

Organization.Name: United States Coast Guard
Organization.History: The roots of the Coast Guard lie in the United States Revenue Cutter Service established by Alexander Hamilton under the Department of the Treasury on 4 August 1790. The first Coast Guard station was in Newburyport, Massachusetts. Until the re-establishment of the United States Navy in 1798, the Revenue Cutter Service was the only naval force of the early United States. It was established to collect taxes from a brand new nation of patriot smugglers. When the officers were out at sea, they were told to crack down on piracy; while they were at it, they might as well rescue anyone in distress.

Organization.Name: American Red Cross
Organization.History: The American Red Cross (ARC), also known as the American National Red Cross, is a humanitarian organization that provides emergency assistance, disaster relief and education inside the United States. It is the designated U.S. affiliate of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies.

Organization.Name: Mexican Government
Organization.History: Mexico, officially the United Mexican States is a federal constitutional republic in North America. It is bordered on the north by the United States of America; on the south and west by the Pacific Ocean; on the southeast by Guatemala, Belize, and the Caribbean Sea; and on the east by the Gulf of Mexico.

Organization.Name: Red Crescent
Organization.History: The Red Cross idea was born in 1859, when Henry Dunant, a young Swiss man, came upon the scene of a bloody battle in Solferino, Italy, between the armies of imperial Austria and the Franco-Sardinian alliance. Some 40,000 men lay dead or dying on the battlefield and the wounded were lacking medical attention.

Organization.Name: Partners in Health
Organization.History: PIH was founded in 1987 to deliver health care to the residents of Haitis mountainous Central Plateau region.

Organization.Name: Americorps
Organization.History: The reasoning behind AmeriCorps comes from a long historical tradition of community service through civic associations.

Organization.Name: Peace Corps
Organization.History: The Peace Corps traces its roots and mission to 1960, when then-Sen. John F. Kennedy challenged students at the University of Michigan to serve their country in the cause of peace by living and working in developing countries.

Organization.Name: International Atomic Energy Agency
Organization.History: The IAEA was created in 1957 in response to the deep fears and expectations resulting from the discovery of nuclear energy.

Organization.Name: United Nations (UN)
Organization.History: The name United Nations, coined by United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt, was first used in the Declaration by United Nations of 1 January 1942, during the Second World War, when representatives of 26 nations pledged their Governments to continue fighting together against the Axis Powers.

Organization.Name: Center for Disease Control (CDC)
Organization.History: The Communicable Diseases Center was founded July 1, 1946 as the successor to the World War II Malaria Control in War Areas program of Office of National Defense Malaria Control Activities.

Organization.Name: New York Fire Department
Organization.History: The origins of the New York City Fire Department go back to 1648 when the first fire ordinance was adopted in what was then the Dutch settlement of New Amsterdam.

Organization.Name: Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA)
Organization.History: Initially created by Presidential Reorganization Plan No. 3 of 1978 and implemented by two Executive Orders on April 1, 1979.

Organization.Name: Central Intelligence Agency
Organization.History: The Central Intelligence Agency was created by Congress with the passage of the National Security Act of 1947, signed into law by President Harry S. Truman. It is the descendant of the Office of Strategic Services (OSS) of World War II, which was dissolved in October 1945 and its functions transferred to the State and War Departments. Eleven months earlier, in 1944, William J. Donovan, the OSS's creator, proposed to President Franklin D. Roosevelt to create a new organization directly supervised by the President: 'which will procure intelligence both by overt and covert methods and will at the same time provide intelligence guidance, determine national intelligence objectives, and correlate the intelligence material collected by all government agencies.' Under his plan, a powerful, centralized civilian agency would have coordinated all the intelligence services. He also proposed that this agency have authority to conduct 'subversive operations abroad,' but 'no police or law enforcement functions, either at home or abroad.'

PostalAddress.StreetAddress: Central Intelligence Agency, Office of Public Affairs

Organization.Name: Hamas
Organization.History: With its takeover of Gaza after the 1967 war with Egypt, Israel hunted down secular Palestinian Liberation Organization factions but dropped the previous Egyptian rulers' harsh restrictions against Islamic activists. In fact, Israel for many years tolerated and at times encouraged Islamic activists and groups as a counterweight to the secular nationalists of the PLO and its dominant faction, Fatah.

Organization.Name: al-Qaeda
Organization.History: The origins of al-Qaeda as a network inspiring terrorism around the world and training operatives can be traced to the Soviet War in Afghanistan (December 1979 - February 1989). The U.S. viewed the conflict in Afghanistan, with the Afghan Marxists and allied Soviet troops on one side and the native Afghan mujahideen, some of whom were radical Islamic militants, on the other, as a blatant case of Soviet expansionism and aggression. A CIA program called Operation Cyclone channeled funds through Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence agency to the Afghan Mujahideen who were fighting the Soviet occupation

Organization.Name: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
Organization.History: When diplomats met to form the United Nations in 1945, one of the things they discussed was setting up a global health organization. WHO’s Constitution came into force on 7 April 1948 – a date we now celebrate every year as World Health Day.

Organization.Name: World Bank
Organization.History: Since inception in 1944, the World Bank has expanded from a single institution to a closely associated group of five development institutions. Our mission evolved from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) as facilitator of post-war reconstruction and development to the present-day mandate of worldwide poverty alleviation in close coordination with our affiliate, the International Development Association, and other members of the World Bank Group, the International Finance Corporation (IFC), the Multilateral Guarantee Agency (MIGA), and the International Centre for the Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID).

Organization.Name: World Food Program
Organization.History: Scheduled to go into operation in 1963 as a three-year experimental programme, WFP was up and running before it could walk.

Organization.Name: Google
Organization.History: Started initially as a research project for Larry Page and Sergey Brin to create a search engine that would rank search results by relevancy and importance

Organization.Name: USGS
Organization.History: Created by an act of Congress on March 3rd 1879 to survey and classify the lands acquired in the Louisiana Purchase and the Mexican War

Organization.Name: UNAMIR
Organization.History: Created by the UN to support the Rwandans during conflict

Organization.Name: Salvation Army
Organization.History: Started by William and Catherine Booth as service organization modeled after military hiarchy under the notion that to be effective the organization need to have the force of an army.

Organization.Name: CARE
Organization.History: CARE was founded in 1945, when 22 American organizations came together to rush lifesaving CARE Packages to survivors of World War II. Thousands of Americans, including President Harry S. Truman, contributed to the effort.

Organization.Name: European Union
Organization.History: After World War II, moves towards European integration were seen by many as an escape from the extreme forms of nationalism that had devastated the continent. As a result, many countries in Europe came together to form communities as a means of avoiding further war. This eventually led to the creation of the European Union and the euro (the single European currency) in 1993.

Organization.Name: Human Rights Watch
Organization.History: Human Rights Watch was founded as a private American NGO in 1978, under the name of Helsinki Watch, to monitor the former Soviet Union's compliance with the Helsinki Accords. Asia Watch (1985), Africa Watch (1988), and Middle East Watch (1989) were added to what was then known as "The Watch Committees." In 1988, all of the committees were united under one umbrella to form Human Rights Watch.

Organization.Name: National Wildlife Federation
Organization.History: Created by Franklin Delano Roosevelt to unite individuals, organizations and agencies interested in the restoration and conservation of wildlife resources.

Organization.Name: Oxfam International
Organization.History: The name "Oxfam" comes from the Oxford Committee for Famine Relief, founded in Britain in 1942. The group campaigned for food supplies to be sent through an allied naval blockade to starving women and children in enemy-occupied Greece during the Second World War. Oxfam International was formed in 1995 by a group of independent non-governmental organizations. Their aim was to work together for greater impact on the international stage to reduce poverty and injustice.

Organization.Name: United Nations Children's Fund
Organization.History: UNICEF was created by the United Nations General Assembly on December 11, 1946, to provide emergency food and healthcare to children in countries that had been devastated by World War II. It has since then provided long-term humanitarian and developmental assistance to children and mothers in developing countries across the world.

Organization.Name: Episcopal Relief and Development
Organization.History: Founded in 1940 to help European refugees during World War II.

Organization.Name: American Humane Association
Organization.History: Founded in 1877. Dedicated to the welfare of animals and children.

Organization.Name: AmeriCares
Organization.History: Founded in 1975 as a response to slow organizational action towards an international crisis involving a crashed jet carrying 243 Vietnamese Orphans. Dedicated to offering immediate and effective aid in worldwide disasters.

Organization.Name: Habitat for Humanity
Organization.History: Founded in 1976. Dedicated to building simple, decent, and affordable housing.

Organization.Name: Disasters Emergency Committee
Organization.History: Founded in 1963 as a conglomerate of 14 individual charities devoted to providing aid to victims of disasters.

Organization.Name: Operation USA
Organization.History: Founded in 1979. Dedicated to providing relief to victims of disaster, disease, and poverty.

Organization.Name: Children's Disaster Services
Organization.History: Founded in 1980 under the Church of the Brethren. Dedicated to providing relief to children in instances of natural or artificial disaster.

Organization.Name: Feeding America
Organization.History: Founded in 1980 to provide food to the needy.

Organization.Name: United States Air Force
Organization.History: As one of the nations premier humanitarian organizations, the American Red Cross is dedicated to helping people in need throughout the United States and, in association with other Red Cross networks, throughout the world. We depend on the many generous contributions of time, blood, and money from the American public to support our lifesaving services and programs.

Organization.Name: Cristian Aid
Organization.History: Founded in the aftermath of WW2 by the UK and Irish Church

Organization.Name: National Guard of the United States
Organization.History: It has helped out in most major world crises.

Organization.Name: Save the Children
Organization.History: Provides Humanitarian Aid with a Focus on Children

Organization.Name: United States Department of Agriculture
Organization.History: On May 15, 1862, Abraham Lincoln signed into law the Agricultural Act that established the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Since then, the Department has had a rich and varied history. The resources below explore that history, along with the history and organization of USDA's associated agencies and staff offices.

Organization.Name: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission
Organization.History: Prior to the enactment of the federal securities laws and the creation of the SEC, there existed so-called blue sky laws. They were enacted and enforced at the state level, and regulated the offering and sale of securities to protect the public from fraud. Though the specific provisions of these laws varied among states, they all required the registration of all securities offerings and sales, as well as of every U.S. stock broker and brokerage firm.

Organization.Name: Federal Department Insurance Corporation
Organization.History: Founded sometime this mellenia.

Organization.Name: Federal Reserve
Organization.History: In 1791, the government granted the First Bank of the United States a charter to operate as the U.S. central bank until 1811. The First Bank of the United States came to an end under President Madison because Congress refused to renew its charter. The Second Bank of the United States was established in. 1816, and lost its authority to be the central bank of the U.S. twenty years later under President Jackson when its charter expired. Both banks were based upon the Bank of England. Ultimately, a third national bank, known as the Federal Reserve, was established in 1913 and still exists to this day.

Organization.Name: Lehman Brothers
Organization.History: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. was a global financial services firm. Before declaring bankruptcy in 2008, Lehman was the fourth-largest investment bank in the US, doing business in investment banking, equity and fixed-income sales and trading (especially U.S. Treasury securities), research, investment management, private equity, and private banking.

Organization.Name: European Central Bank
Organization.History: The European Central Bank (ECB) is one of the seven institutions of the European Union (EU) listed in the Treaty on European Union(TEU). It is the central bank for the euro and administers the monetary policy of the 17 EU member states which constitute the Eurozone, one of the largest currency areas in the world. It is thus one of the world's most important central banks.

Organization.Name: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
Organization.History: Founded 1970-10-03

Organization.Name: Forestry Commission Great Britain
Organization.History: Founded 1919-01-01

Organization.Name: Humanity First
Organization.History: Founded 1994-01-01

Organization.Name: Haiti Relief Fund
Organization.History: Founded 2010-01-12

Organization.Name: Hurricane Sandy Relief Foundation
Organization.History: Founded 2012-10-30

Organization.Name: Japan Earthquake Relief Fund
Organization.History: Founded 2011-03-12

CrisisKind.Name: War
CrisisKind.Description: An organized and often prolonged conflict that is carried out by states and/or non-state actors.

CrisisKind.Name: Volcano
CrisisKind.Description: a vent in the earth's crust through which lava, steam, ashes, etc., are expelled, either continuously or at irregular intervals.

CrisisKind.Name: Hurricane
CrisisKind.Description: a violent, tropical, cyclonic storm of the western North Atlantic, having wind speeds of or in excess of 72 miles per hour

CrisisKind.Name: Weapons
CrisisKind.Description: Anything used against an opponent, adversary, or victim

CrisisKind.Name: Disease
CrisisKind.Description: A disease resulting from pathogenic biological agents in an host organism

CrisisKind.Name: Genocide
CrisisKind.Description: The deliberate and systematic destruction of an ethnic, racial, religious, or national group

CrisisKind.Name: Transnational Organized Crime
CrisisKind.Description: Organized crime coordinated across national borders, involving groups workin in more than one country to plan and execute illegal business ventures

CrisisKind.Name: Accident
CrisisKind.Description: A result of human error

CrisisKind.Name: Conflic
CrisisKind.Description: Two forces in disagreement

CrisisKind.Name: Earthquake
CrisisKind.Description: Shifting of tectonic plates. Measured on Richter scale

CrisisKind.Name: Economic Crises
CrisisKind.Description: Financial instability

CrisisKind.Name: Fire
CrisisKind.Description: Massive damage due to fire

CrisisKind.Name: Flood
CrisisKind.Description: Massive amounts of water in a condensed area

CrisisKind.Name: Food Crisis
CrisisKind.Description: Lack of essential nutrients

CrisisKind.Name: Terrorist Attack
CrisisKind.Description: Surprise attack from a group with political or religious aim

CrisisKind.Name: Tornada
CrisisKind.Description: Funnel shaped vortex with extremely high winds

CrisisKind.Name: Tsunami
CrisisKind.Description: Massive wave. Sometimes resulting from earthquakes

CrisisKind.Name: Other
CrisisKind.Description: Everything else

CrisisKind.Name: Meteor
CrisisKind.Description: visible streak of light from a meteoroid or micrometeoroid, heated and glowing from entering the Earth's atmosphere, as it sheds glowing material in its wake.

CrisisKind.Name: Disease
CrisisKind.Description: A disease outbreak

CrisisKind.Name: Storm
CrisisKind.Description: A storm

CrisisKind.Name: Natural Disaster
CrisisKind.Description: A natural event causes the crisis (e.g. flood, tornado, hurricane, earthquake, volcano, etc.)

CrisisKind.Name: International Political Scandal
CrisisKind.Description: A political scandal between nations that causes severe tensions in their relationship.

CrisisKind.Name: Blockage
CrisisKind.Description: One party ensures that the other party does not receive any resources in a bid to force them into submission.

OrganizationKind.Name: National Government
OrganizationKind.Description: The government of a nation

OrganizationKind.Name: Humanitarian Organization
OrganizationKind.Description: Organization that provides humanitarian aid

OrganizationKind.Name: International Organization
OrganizationKind.Description: Organization that provides leveraged loans to poor countries

OrganizationKind.Name: Military Alliance
OrganizationKind.Description: An agreement between two, or more, military factions

OrganizationKind.Name: Public Health Advocate
OrganizationKind.Description: An organization that aims to influence public-policy and resource allocation decisions within political, economic, and social systems and institutions for public heal needs.

OrganizationKind.Name: Government Military Branch
OrganizationKind.Description: A military brach of a government (or governments) that carries out the orders received, whether that be active combat or humanitarian aide

OrganizationKind.Name: Health
OrganizationKind.Description: Designed to promote health relief and education

OrganizationKind.Name: Public Service
OrganizationKind.Description: Groups dedicated to helping the public and its instutions

OrganizationKind.Name: Disaster Relief
OrganizationKind.Description: Providing relief to areas of recent/ongoing disaster whether natural or non-natural.

OrganizationKind.Name: Governmental Organization
OrganizationKind.Description: Administrative unit of the government designed to improve a specific area.

OrganizationKind.Name: Agricultural Department
OrganizationKind.Description: Agriculutural Department

OrganizationKind.Name: Animal Protection Agency
OrganizationKind.Description: Animal Protection Agency

OrganizationKind.Name: Central Bank
OrganizationKind.Description: Central Bank

OrganizationKind.Name: Charitable Organization
OrganizationKind.Description: Charitable Organization

OrganizationKind.Name: Economic and Political Union
OrganizationKind.Description: Economic and Political Union

OrganizationKind.Name: Environmental Organization
OrganizationKind.Description: Environmental Organization

OrganizationKind.Name: Insurance Corporation
OrganizationKind.Description: Insurance Corporation

OrganizationKind.Name: Investment Bank
OrganizationKind.Description: Investment Bank

OrganizationKind.Name: Military Organization
OrganizationKind.Description: Military Organization

OrganizationKind.Name: National Security
OrganizationKind.Description: Tends to matters of national security

OrganizationKind.Name: Non-Profit Organization
OrganizationKind.Description: Non-Profit Organization

OrganizationKind.Name: Social Organization
OrganizationKind.Description: Social Organization

OrganizationKind.Name: Miscellaneous
OrganizationKind.Description: Organizations that did not fall into any other category

OrganizationKind.Name: Humanitarian Aid
OrganizationKind.Description: Concerned with or seeking to promote human welfare: "groups sending humanitarian aid".

OrganizationKind.Name: Disaster Relief Agency
OrganizationKind.Description: Provides aid in the aftermath of a disaster.

OrganizationKind.Name: Non-Profit
OrganizationKind.Description: A Non-Profit organization uses surplus revenues to achieve its goals (usually humanitarian) rather than distributing them as profit or dividends.

OrganizationKind.Name: Government Organization
OrganizationKind.Description: A body of the Government responsible for non-defence, non-intelligence business.

PersonKind.Name: President (current or former)
PersonKind.Description: A democratically elected leader of a government

PersonKind.Name: Dictator
PersonKind.Description: Leader of a dictatorship, someone with sole and absolute power

PersonKind.Name: Governor
PersonKind.Description: Person served as Governor of a state in the United States

PersonKind.Name: Philanthropist
PersonKind.Description: Person uses their influence to help make positive changes in the world

PersonKind.Name: Humanitarian
PersonKind.Description: Having the interests of mankind at heart

PersonKind.Name: Head of Organization
PersonKind.Description: Leader/CEO/Owner of an organization. The person in charge

PersonKind.Name: Researcher
PersonKind.Description: A person designated to study and gather information.

PersonKind.Name: Businessman/woman
PersonKind.Description: A person in the business of selling/trading goods

PersonKind.Name: Politician
PersonKind.Description: A person who is professionally involved in politics (The activities associated with the governance of a country or area)

PersonKind.Name: Leader
PersonKind.Description: Leader of an organization

PersonKind.Name: Prime Minister
PersonKind.Description: Leader of a Kingdom

PersonKind.Name: Singer
PersonKind.Description: Sings songs

PersonKind.Name: Chairman
PersonKind.Description: A chairman

PersonKind.Name: CEO
PersonKind.Description: A Cheif Executive Officer

PersonKind.Name: Federal Reserve Chairman
PersonKind.Description: A federal reserve chairman

PersonKind.Name: Founder
PersonKind.Description: A person who founded something

PersonKind.Name: Government Official
PersonKind.Description: A government official

PersonKind.Name: Personality
PersonKind.Description: A person well known in pop culture

PersonKind.Name: President and CEO
PersonKind.Description: A president and CEO of a company

PersonKind.Name: Secretary of Agriculture
PersonKind.Description: A secretary of agriculture

PersonKind.Name: Social Worker
PersonKind.Description: A social worker

PersonKind.Name: Terrorist Leader
PersonKind.Description: A terrorist leader

PersonKind.Name: United States Ambassador
PersonKind.Description: A US Ambassador

PersonKind.Name: Vice President
PersonKind.Description: A vice president of a country

PersonKind.Name: Others
PersonKind.Description: Another person that is not listed
